title: Macro Live, Janet Yellen presser edition

teaser.title: Macro Live, Janet Yellen presser edition

bodyHTML:
7:22 pm
CG7:22pm

Hello!

CG7:24pm

We're experiencing technical difficulties and can't promise resolution

CG7:24pm

But we'll forge ahead until the meltdown is complete

7:24 pm
MCK7:24pm

Cardiff, you need to have faith that it's just "transitory"

CG7:24pm

I'm trying to see past it, Matt, and make my judgement based on teh underlying trends

CG7:25pm

anyways, let's do links

7:24 pm
CG7:25pm

Here are the new SEPs

CG7:25pm

https://www.federa...ojtabl20170920.pdf

CG7:25pm

Hi Gia, Acker, John D and Chief

7:25 pm
MCK7:25pm

Here is the statement https://www.federa...etary20170920a.htm

MCK7:26pm

And here is the "implementation note", which has the details on how they will let the balance sheet shrink https://www.federa...tary20170920a1.htm

CG7:26pm

The important new line is this:

7:26 pm
CG7:26pm

In October, the Committee will initiate the balance sheet normalization program described in the June 2017 Addendum to the Committee's Policy Normalization Principles and Plans.

CG7:26pm

Totally expected, but what's about to happen is that the Fed will stop reinvesting the proceeds from the maturation of its current debt holdings. But

MCK7:27pm

And the longer version, from the implementation note

7:26 pm
MCK7:27pm

Effective in October 2017, the Committee directs the Desk to roll over at auction the amount of principal payments from the Federal Reserve's holdings of Treasury securities maturing during each calendar month that exceeds $6 billion, and to reinvest in agency mortgage-backed securities the amount of principal payments from the Federal Reserve's holdings of agency debt and agency mortgage-backed securities received during each calendar month that exceeds $4 billion. Small deviations from these amounts for operational reasons are acceptable.

CG7:27pm

while the Treasury portfolio will shrink at a highly predictable pace,

CG7:28pm

the reduction in the MBS portfolio depends on how quickly Americans prepay their mortgage debt

7:28 pm
CG7:28pm

Rates were unchanged, as expected

CG7:28pm

And what we'll be listening for in the presser

CG7:28pm

is the extent to which the Fed interprets the balance sheet reduction as something that needs to be offset by a slower pace of rate hikes

7:28 pm
MCK7:29pm

The mortgage prepayment issue could be interesting, since any big rise in long rates would sharply reduce refinancings, thereby keeping Fed balance sheet somewhat bigger than they might like

CG7:30pm

Here's one prediction for how quickly this might happen, via Lew Alexander at Nomura:

CG7:30pm

7:30 pm
MCK7:31pm

@Gia, $10b/month initially, but could increase

CG7:31pm

Gonna share a couple of other useful charts from this note, mostly self-explanatory

MCK7:31pm

You can start watching the press conference here https://www.federalreserve.gov/

7:31 pm
CG7:31pm

(PRESSER STARTING BTW)

MCK7:32pm

@Acker, that is correct

CG7:32pm

7:32 pm
CG7:32pm

MCK7:33pm

A few things to note from the economic projections:

MCK7:33pm

First, the "longer-run" forecast for the policy rate dropped to a new all-time low of 2.75%, or 0.75% after expected inflation

7:34 pm
CG7:34pm

The basic idea is that longer rates will be affected by combination of two things: the expected path of short rates, and a term premium. Their relative contributions are tough to pin down, but the balance sheet effects are thought to affect the term premia directly. (The question is, how much?) This is a framework that dates back to the Bernanke era.

MCK7:34pm

Second, we have the first batch of interest rate projections for the end of 2020. As of now there are 9 Fed officials who expect the policy rate to be above its "longer-run" level by the end of 2020 -- that means deliberately tight policy

CG7:35pm

Yellen still reading her prepared notes. We'll start the real-time commentary in earnest when the Q&A starts

7:35 pm
CG7:36pm

She's now noting transitory effects from mobile pricing, etc going down, and the hurricane effects going up

MCK7:36pm

Finally, OIS rates imply less than 10% chance that the Fed will actually raise rates by the end of 2018 as much as currently forecast

MCK7:36pm

@Cliff, they are still arguing about it, part of the issue is that the Fed wants to accommodate "natural" growth in demand for physical currency, which they can't fully predict

7:37 pm
CG7:37pm

"Our understanding of the forces driving inflation is imperfect."

MCK7:38pm

Another interesting thing about the longer-run forecasts: Fed expects US economy to slow significantly over next few years, from 2.4% rgdp growth this year to 1.8% by 2020, yet they plan to raise rates above "neutral" over that period

CG7:38pm

IT WASN'T ME I DIDN'T

7:38 pm
CG7:39pm

huh, quite the contradiction

CG7:40pm

matt, the fed in 2020 appears to expect slower than long-run growth, yet well below long-run unemployment

MCK7:40pm

Does imply that unemployment will go up in 2021-2023

7:41 pm
CG7:41pm

central tendency at 4-4.5, yet long-run unemployment estimate still 4.5-4.8

CG7:41pm

veeeeery peculiar

MCK7:41pm

Balance sheet will decline "gradually and predictably", says Yellen

7:42 pm
MCK7:42pm

Fed seems to be aiming for a slowdown/recession sometime during or just after the next presidential election

MCK7:42pm

Should be interesting...

MCK7:43pm

Question time!

7:42 pm
CG7:43pm

Q&A starting

MCK7:44pm

First up: Bloomberg asking why Fed wants to keep unemployment above 4% when inflation is still quiescent

CG7:44pm

raises the good point that unemployment for some parts of the population, specifically for african americans, remains much higher than for others

7:44 pm
CG7:44pm

nearly double, if i remember correctly

CG7:45pm

Yellen saying that for these groups (african american and hispanic americans) unemployment has fallen even faster, though still high up

MCK7:45pm

Yellen says that "we have to be mindful of 2% inflation objective over medium term"

7:45 pm
CG7:46pm

She says she has to balance it against inflation, acknowledges the shortfall inthe last few years

MCK7:46pm

In the past she has defined "medium term" to be further than 6 years in the future

CG7:46pm

She now says labour market slack has "largely disappeared"

7:46 pm
MCK7:46pm

Sorry, "medium term" is 2-6 years https://ftalphavil...ou-think-it-means/

CG7:46pm

plus dollar this year has weakened, whereas before a strong dollar was also keeping a lid on inflation

MCK7:48pm

"forecasts are not set in stone, not definite plans" -- Yellen

7:48 pm
CG7:48pm

repeats that the committee expects inflation to move up towards its target throughout next year

MCK7:48pm

(This explains why interest rate forecasts have continually dropped ever since they started publishing them)

MCK7:49pm

"Monetary policy operates with a lag"

7:49 pm
CG7:49pm

doesn't want to have to tighten policy so quickly later, if the economy reheats, that it causes a recession

MCK7:49pm

Next question from our very own Sam Fleming

CG7:49pm

Sam "Green Eggs and Ham" Fleming!

7:49 pm
CG7:50pm

asks about asset markets

MCK7:50pm

Sam wants to know about how financial conditions are affecting policy deliberations

MCK7:50pm

In other words, if stocks go up and spreads tighten, should Fed hike more than originally planned?

7:51 pm
CG7:51pm

bit of a wishy-washy answer, but in fairness this is a wishy-washy issue

CG7:52pm

depends on what's causing the asset price movements, but of course noobody knows that for sure

CG7:52pm

but the bit on sec-stag was interesting, as Nick highlights (hi Nick!)

7:52 pm
MCK7:53pm

CNBC wants to know what forces could affect balance sheet shrinkage plan (market shocks, fiscal stuff, etc)

MCK7:54pm

"Historically, the committee has operated...by adjusting the Federal Funds rate. That's a technique of monetary control we've used for a very long time. We believe we understand it pretty well"

MCK7:54pm

(Hi Nick!)

7:22 pm
MCK7:22pm

Hello everyone!

MCK7:55pm

Deep belief within the Fed that they "understand" how short rates work and are comfortable with that tool, compared to fear of "unfamiliar" balance sheet tools

MCK7:55pm

I can't say I get it given how much disagreement there is on transmission effects of short rates...

7:55 pm
CG7:55pm

not even really an imitation: more like yield curve targeting by a different name, but of course that depends on extent to which the fed does indeed see the two tools as a substitute. the more deliberate reason for all this is the one matt just mentioned: discomfort with a big balance sheet

MCK7:56pm

CG, targeting yield curve could make sense, especially given how flat it's gotten and how that tends to predict downturns well

CG7:57pm

yep, could work, though of course this wouldn't be the only way to do it. Reverse Twist operations would be as effective, and then you'd get to keep the large balance sheet, but that's not on the table

7:57 pm
MCK7:57pm

@John, unemployment is both 14% and 4%, depends on what exactly you're trying to count...

CG7:57pm

Binya A from the NYT asks what would happen if the economy turns towards recession again

CG7:57pm

re the balance sheet, etc...

7:57 pm
CG7:57pm

"hurdle to chaning plans with respect to the balance sheet" is high

MCK7:58pm

Good point CG, also by letting balance sheet shrink organically, the Fed could end up lengthening duration of its remaining portfolio

MCK7:58pm

Because shortest bonds mature first

7:57 pm
CG7:58pm

indeed

CG7:59pm

Binya follows up by asking if Fed has enough room to respond

CG7:59pm

in another recession

7:59 pm
MCK7:59pm

@Acker, if there is a lot of disagreement then the truth is mysterious, no?

CG8:00pm

Nick T asks about Brainard's speech!

MCK8:01pm

"What would we need to do to boost trend inflation if it's fallen?"

8:00 pm
CG8:01pm

in which she (Brainard) argued that underlying inflation was lower now

MCK8:01pm

"There are a variety of statistical techniques to extract a trend from a series" -- thanks

CG8:02pm

"underlying" a murky concept, but related to some combination of real-world conditions and inflation expectations

8:03 pm
CG8:03pm

if you're wondering what nick is talking about: "The Hodrick Prescott (HP) filter is a commonly used tool in macroeconomics, and is used to extract a trend component from a time series."

MCK8:03pm

More seriously, it's tough to determine whether the trend has changed or whether you are just deviating from the trend.

CG8:03pm

Yellen just mentioned it

8:04 pm
CG8:04pm

MCK, agree, Yellen is right in her implicit suggestion that the concept is murky

MCK8:04pm

Interesting distinction between Fed's confidence that the trend for RGDP has fallen irreversibly (see their output gap estimates) and its confidence that trend for inflation has not.

CG8:05pm

question about why markets are pricing in a shallower path for rate hikes

8:05 pm
CG8:06pm

MCK, think the idea is that the Fed can influence the latter more than the former, which is also driven by structural factors (make of that what you will, but I think that's the rationale)

MCK8:07pm

"Market participants may believe low neutral rate may be more persistent...there is nothing set in stone about policy paths" "Not only disagreement, also uncertainty"

MCK8:09pm

Yellen thinks market-implied path of short rates looks lower than Fed's forecasts because of "negative term premia"

8:09 pm
CG8:09pm

huh, interesting point about negative term premia

CG8:09pm

stays coy about her own future, which of course she can't really discuss

MCK8:10pm

Question now about gap in gains between asset-owners and the rest

8:10 pm
MCK8:11pm

Basically it's easier to point to gains to homeowners and shareholders than the large chunk of Americans who are neither

MCK8:11pm

(although there are counterfactuals involving unemployment and wages etc)

CG8:14pm

lengthy exchange about the volcker rule, now addressing problematic issues of income distribution after the crisis

8:14 pm
CG8:14pm

says monetary policy isn't set with view to affect income distribution but to hit its congressionally mandated (macro) goals

MCK8:14pm

@Acker, that's correct, but it's also "trickle-down" monetary policy

MCK8:16pm

"I will greatly miss Vice Chair Fischer"

8:16 pm
CG8:16pm

question about the fact that Fischer leaving and there's basically nobody on the Fed board of governors (only ones left are yellen, brainard, powell)

CG8:17pm

brainard and powell are heading all the other committee now, tim duy had a great post about this

MCK8:17pm

"I would welcome a full complement of colleagues. We have a lot of work to do and it would be nice to distribute it among more people"

8:17 pm
CG8:17pm

says she's had good interactions and hopes he will be confirmed

CG8:17pm

wants a full suite of colleagues

MCK8:18pm

Big skills mismatch at FOMC, evidently, given high openings and low level of hires #JOLTS

8:18 pm
CG8:18pm

they should raise wages!

MCK8:19pm

@Acker, not sure there is a bigger one than the wealth effect, although Tobias Adrian and Hyun Song Shin have done interesting things on relationship between short rates and bank leverage

CG8:19pm

(that's a joke, rabble, kindly not to @ me)

8:19 pm
CG8:19pm

question about the appalling behavior by Wells Fargo in screwing its customers,

MCK8:20pm

CG, Fed governor salaries are quite low both in international terms and relative to salaries of regional Fed presidents

CG8:21pm

Damn it Matt, "Don't @ me" referred to you too!

8:21 pm
MCK8:21pm

Carney and Draghi both make way more than Yellen, for example

MCK8:21pm

Teeth smile

CG8:22pm

btw, “I consider the behavior of Wells Fargo toward its customers to have been egregious and unacceptable" was (appropriately) strong, brought the tone too

8:22 pm
MCK8:22pm

Will be interesting to see if Fed follows through on Yellen's attitude to Wells

MCK8:23pm

https://twitter.com/tylltt/status/910584799970066433

CG8:24pm

lol

8:25 pm
CG8:26pm

question about whether designation Sifi is a process that should be changed

CG8:29pm

Wells, Equifax, Volcker Rule -- may as well go whole hog and ask about cryptocurrencies

CG8:29pm

like a tour of financial market pathologies. What's up with Goldman Sachs buying Venezuelan debt directly from its central bank?

8:30 pm
MCK8:30pm

"Will the Fed buy cryptocurrencies in the next recession? If so, what criteria will you use to determine shape of asset purchases?" -- the FUTURE

MCK8:31pm

"Will there be a cryptocurrency capital key? Must all crypto assets have at least one investment-grade rating to be included in the program?"

CG8:31pm

"Chair Yellen, have you met Izabella Kaminska?"

8:33 pm
CG8:33pm

"Do you agree that the introduction of Utility Settlement Coin risks the migration of wholesale fundings markets onto SIVs? Is it all just a ludicrous game of 'pass the technological infrastructure costs'?"

MCK8:33pm

"We've had four or five years in which inflation has been running below our inflation objective even though we've been interested in achieving it" -- Yellen

CG8:34pm

(sorry, I'll stop)

8:35 pm
MCK8:35pm

(Wait until the Fed announces an emergency swap line for Bitcoin exchanges...)

CG8:35pm

says above 120,000 payroll monthly gains is consistent with tightening labour market given labour force entrants. I don't know if I've heard her give that precise an estimate about this before, but possibly i've forgotten

CG8:36pm

aaaaand scene

8:35 pm
MCK8:36pm

/fin

CG8:36pm

okay, the presser is ovver

CG8:36pm

matt and i will be re-living the drama again at 4pm on facebook live if anybody wants to join us

8:36 pm
CG8:36pm

I forgot to shave this morning just for you, rabble

CG8:37pm

so go to the FT's facebook page to catch us

MCK8:37pm

(I did not forget to shave)

8:37 pm
CG8:37pm

Nick, I too thought the number was a bit lower, but admittedly i haven't checked in a while

MCK8:38pm

Those estimates are very sensitive to assumptions about demographics, lfpr, immigration, etc

CG8:48pm

okay everyone, we gotta go! thanks so much for joining us, catch you in December

7:54 pm
CG7:54pm

something interesting about all this is the extent to which selling assets from its holdings (none of which are short-term bills) combined with a weaker path of short-rate hikes is an imitation of yield curve targeting
originalTitle: Macro Live, Janet Yellen presser edition
